{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3660906,"name":"Rocky Xu","username":"RockyXRQ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rockyxrq/{size}/261789_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T04:58:53.737Z","cooked":"

Hey CD!

Team 8214 Cyber Unicorn here. Our team is currently rethinking our approach to Ethernet cables, and we’d love to get some community wisdom on a few things we’re stuck on.

Ethernet cables are the lifelines of our robots’ communication systems, connecting everything from the radio and switches to the roboRIO, coprocessors, and the Driver Station. But when we started looking into it, we realized there’s a huge variety of cables out there. You’ve got different standards like CAT5E, CAT6, and CAT6A, and a whole world of shielding types like UTP (Unshielded Twisted Pair), F/UTP (Foiled, Unshielded Twisted Pair), and S/FTP (Shielded, Foiled Twisted Pair). Not to mention the classic debate of buying pre-made vs. crimping your own.

So, we wanted to throw a few questions out to the community:

  1. For FRC, is sticking with CAT5E totally fine, or is there a real, tangible benefit to investing in higher-spec cables like CAT6 or beyond?

  2. How crucial is shielding on an FRC robot, which can be a very noisy electrical environment? We see a lot of debate between using standard UTP cables versus shielded types. If shielding is recommended, is it worth going all the way to something more robust like S/FTP?

  3. What’s your team’s philosophy on pre-made vs. custom-crimped cables? Do you prioritize the reliability of factory-molded connectors, or the flexibility of making your own custom lengths right when you need them? We’d love to hear the ‘why’ behind your choice.

Any advice or insights you could share would be super helpful and greatly appreciated!

Thanks a bunch!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T04:59:20.803Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":441,"readers_count":440,"score":233.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Rocky Xu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49303,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 8214 programming mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660909,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T05:02:24.242Z","cooked":"

We standardize on the monoprice slim run cables. They are thin for easy for wire management, have the full boot and clip so they stay reliable, and they come in lots of colors and lengths.

https://amzn.to/4ebBRkI

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T05:02:24.242Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":401,"readers_count":400,"score":310.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://amzn.to/4ebBRkI","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com: Monoprice - 116323 SlimRun Cat6A Ethernet Patch Cable - Snagless RJ45 UTP Pure Bare Copper Wire 10G 30AWG 3ft Purple 10-Pack : Electronics","clicks":139}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":14}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":14}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660916,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T05:06:09.305Z","cooked":"

we’ve sometimes found the “micro” version of these monoprice cables to be worthwhile: they have less boot and so fit in smaller places, like if you have a zillion cables coming out of a switch.

Hey Allen! Thanks for the quick reply! I see the cable you recommended is the unshielded type. Just curious, have you guys ever considered using a shielded one? The one you pointed out is super easy to find in my area, which makes it really tempting to me!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T05:07:57.248Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":390,"readers_count":389,"score":108.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Rocky Xu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":10647,"username":"AllenGregoryIV","name":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49303,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 8214 programming mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660926,"name":"Fletcher","username":"FletcherS7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletchers7/{size}/168995_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T05:17:15.815Z","cooked":"

Some background, I work in Enterprise IT and Network Engineering.

CAT 5e is perfectly suitable for FRC.
You do not need CAT 6 or CAT6a.

There is nothing really on an FRC robot that would require shielded Ethernet, its more important to keep your robot radio high up and away from motors then it is any cables.

Typical rule of thumb is to use COTS Ethernet unless you have a specific need that requires making your own.
Side note, you should not need to glue your Ethernet cables, if a cable is not staying seated, it should be replaced.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T05:17:40.077Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":360,"readers_count":359,"score":182.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Fletcher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25039,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between."},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660927,"name":"Rocky Xu","username":"RockyXRQ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rockyxrq/{size}/261789_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T05:21:56.266Z","cooked":"

Thank you so much, Fletcher! It’s great to hear from a professional! I believe I now have a much better understanding of how to select the right network cables.

We modified a COTS Cat5e cable for the RoboRIOv2 to Vivid Radio link, cutting the power lines (Blue and brown pairs).

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T06:31:03.187Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":98.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660986,"name":"Justin Tervay","username":"jtrv","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jtrv/{size}/203436_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T11:37:17.800Z","cooked":"

Conversely, I’ve had a lot of good results with the Monoprice Micro SlimRun, which don’t have the full boot but are even smaller. Have even run passive POE with these with no issue.

https://www.monoprice.com/product?p_id=34267

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T11:37:17.800Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":296,"readers_count":295,"score":99.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Justin Tervay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.monoprice.com/product?p_id=34267","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":46}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":10647,"username":"AllenGregoryIV","name":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19731,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3660991,"name":"Curt Rozeboom","username":"BlueEpiphone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T12:15:26.522Z","cooked":"

In addition to on-robot Ethernet, you should consider investing in a few of these retractable cables for using on the practice fields. The little 1M cords they come with are also nice to use in the pits. We’ve also used cables similar to @jtrv for those tight spaces on the robot.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T12:15:26.522Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":287,"readers_count":286,"score":147.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Curt Rozeboom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://a.co/d/hh3VgbB","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com: EXTNGO Retractable Network Cable Extender, 50 Feet CAT 6 Ethernet Cable Flat-Portable 1Gbps Data Speed-Swiftly Setup Temp Networks-Cascadable Male-Female RJ45 Connector-UTP Cable Reel : Electronics","clicks":43}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32089,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5010 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661021,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T13:37:51.250Z","cooked":"

Do folks find these retractable cables actually work/last? We purchased one from AndyMark a couple years back during build season, and it stopped working within a week of light use.

It seemed like a great idea in theory, but at $50-$75USD per unit, I’m pretty hesitant to get another if it’s going to break on us so quickly…

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T13:37:51.250Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":260,"readers_count":259,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/extngo-retractable-ethernet-cable-50-feet","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"EXTNGO Retractable Ethernet Cable 50 feet - AndyMark, Inc","clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":32089,"username":"BlueEpiphone","name":"Curt Rozeboom","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661027,"name":"Curt Rozeboom","username":"BlueEpiphone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T13:50:26.382Z","cooked":"

The one I listed, which we’ve bought in the past, can break if the robot takes off too quickly and it pulls on the end which I wouldn’t classify as light-use. This has happened enough that we’re needing to replace ours for next season, so yeah it’s an investment to protect. Otherwise, we’ve not had issues with it on the whole under normal use, just spooling/unspooling. However, that’s no different than using any other non-spooled cable, really. I was just talking to another mentor about coupling a mini-retractor like the one that comes with it to the unspooled end so that if we do get into a tug-of-war with the robot, the retractor deploys enough cable to allow the driver to stop before actually ripping the cable. Ultimately, if you’re on a practice field where you can run an auto or let your driver do some fast moves, you need to be very careful with your cable! Most typical practice-fields are the station-oriented ones that don’t allow for that, so it’s usually fine. We’ve only run into this at DCMPs or Worlds where larger ones are available.

Edit - Checking your AM link, it looks like the same product, though.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T13:53:44.506Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":258,"readers_count":257,"score":111.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Curt Rozeboom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32089,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5010 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661036,"name":"","username":"LPryor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T14:46:00.620Z","cooked":"

Co-sign. I use these cables in my house as well.

Shielding shouldn’t be an issue and we’ve found CAT5 to be more than enough bandwidth.

Really any quality cable will do. One recommendation I have is buy a cable tester and include using it in your pre-event checklist.

I would avoid making your own like the plague. The crimpers are tricky to use and the only thing you really gain is a custom length which isn’t worth the risk IMHO.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T14:56:09.988Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":209.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":10647,"username":"AllenGregoryIV","name":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55309,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 8280, President Motor City Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/12","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661045,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T15:07:52.861Z","cooked":"

We bought the same branded one, and I agree, it was flaky the first couple times we used it, and then stopped working completely. It was a big waste of money.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T15:07:52.861Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":212,"readers_count":211,"score":117.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/13","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661077,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T15:29:41.313Z","cooked":"

I suggest AGAINST crimping your own cables. It’s a useful skill, but it’s possible to screw up in ways that aren’t immediately obvious – a wire that might work great for data might have a problem with the PoE pins, for example.

I also suggest IN FAVOR to teaching students how to coil wire (the overhand/underhand technique works well) and why it’s important. (But, not all that relevant to any wires actually contained inside the robot.)

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T15:29:41.313Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":115.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/14","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661431,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T18:40:16.527Z","cooked":"

The flat ethernet cables are generally stranded and thus last much longer in tethering. Solid core is the common stuff andnit fatigues out quite quickly.
@BlueEpiphone is right on; those as good a cable reel as you can buy. Gotta remind the kiddos to always pull the whole thing out when tethering!

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-06-23T18:40:16.527Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":175,"readers_count":174,"score":95.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503515,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-ethernet-cables","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-ethernet-cables/503515/15","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3661623,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-23T20:22:06.091Z","cooked":"

We crimp our own Ethernet cables on our robot. I think it’s important to use stranded cable and a good boot to mitigate fatigue issues. If you find the boot makes it too difficult to release the cable, you can trim the part that covers the release without compromising the strain relief.

We use the following 28AWG cable and connectors from InfiniteCables. I like this style of ethernet connector rather than the style where the individual wires stick out the front and then are trimmed short. I think this reduces the chance of a short, and makes it much easier to assemble since the wires are fed through the insert before being trimmed and inserted into the connector.

Infinite Cables US

500ft 4 Pair CAT6 UTP Stranded 28AWG Ultra-Thin Bulk Cable FT4

Overview This riser rated Cat6 bulk cable is 500 feet in length and consists of 4 pairs of 28AWG stranded wires. It is typically used to manufacture Cat6 ultra-thin patch cables and terminated with Cat6 RJ45 plugs designed for ultra-thin cable. Note:...

Price: USD 81.78

Infinite Cables US

RJ45 Cat6a Plug for Slim Cable (Stranded) (8P 8C)

This modular RJ45 Cat6a connector for slim cable is a 8 position, 8 conductor plug. It's typically terminated on 8 conductor stranded round cable. They are available as 50 packs. Physical Characteristics Color Transparent Material Polycarbonate...

Price: USD 11.41

Infinite Cables US

RJ45 CAT6a Boot for Slim Cable - Clear - Pack of 50

This boot sits flush with a RJ45 plug and is inserted onto the plug prior to crimping. The protective hood prevents the RJ45 release clip from snagging. Physical Characteristics Color Clear Material PVC Boot Style Tab Inside Diameter 3.85mm...

Price: USD 4.00

Edit: Oh yeah, if you crimp your own ethernet cables, you can also label what device each cable goes to with heat shrink labels, compatible with a label maker you probably already have. If you have a Brother P-Touch, some the generic ones have a larger compatibility list than the official ones by pretending to be a different kind of label. Check compatibility before buying.

Are the Slim Run cables at 30 or 32 AWG mentioned in this thread legal to use on a robot? R622 states that signal level cables need to be at least 28 AWG. Are Ethernet cables not considered signal level cables?

Interesting, the table on FRCManual.com seems to be not entirely updated. The official game manual lists 26 AWG, (27 SWG or 0.14 mm^2), and Cat5e/6/7/8 cable, single pair next to roboRIO PWM port outputs or ≤1A fuse protected circuit, the category above signal wires, but then lists only 28 AWG and (29 SWG or .08 mm2) next to signal wires. It seems unclear to me whether those Cat wires can be smaller gauge (or if they are required to be fully copper if they are used for PWM/<1A circuits, since only signal wires are allowed to be anything but copper).

It is obvious that the right side of the table is not strictly AND, since not all PWM outputs are required to use Cat cables. But is it strictly OR, where Cat cables can ignore the wire gauge requirements?

ngreen:

We modified a COTS Cat5e cable for the RoboRIOv2 to Vivid Radio link, cutting the power lines (Blue and brown pairs).

What advantage does this give you?

Ryan_Reed:

if you crimp your own ethernet cables, you can also label what device each cable goes to with heat shrink labels, compatible with a label maker you probably already have.

One of our students found a way to print across the width of the 18mm Brother tapes, emulating the labels from the Panduit label maker at my last work place. The labels could fit a wide variety of wire bundle sizes and were always readable since the text was repeated many times on each label. Those wide tape cartridges were far easier to find than the heat shrink tube cartridges. We used these to label all the cables and wire pairs in our 2025 robot.

philso:

What advantage does this give you?

From R703:

*Use specific Ethernet port for roboRIO. The roboRIO Ethernet port must be connected to either

…

B. the port labeled “RIO” of a VH-109 radio via (either directly, or via a Cat5 Ethernet pigtail) an RPM, passive PoE injector cable or adapter (whether or not it is used to power the radio), or an Ethernet cable with the appropriate wires removed on the roboRIO end. All wires or adapters used must be fully insulated.

…

(emphasis mine)
